body:
Currently, most Cython users have to implement code in their `setup.py` files to decide whether to recompile the `.pyx` sources with Cython or not, and what to do if Cython is not installed. Essentially this dance:

http://docs.cython.org/en/latest/src/reference/compilation.html#distributing-cython-modules

[PEP 517](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0517/) and [PEP 518](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0518/) provide ways to configure certain build system tools for a given project. This can be used to provide a simple Cython build package that does this once and for all, is distributed separately via PyPI, and internally calls Cython when necessary and requested, but otherwise just replaces the `.pyx` files by pre-generated `.c` files that come with the source distribution.

It would become a dependency of Cython itself and some parts of the `cythonize()` implementation would be moved into the new build package. Meaning, most of the code is already there in one way or another, just needs to be extracted and cleanly put into an external package.

Also see #1981, which could be solved at the same time (in a single package).

comment_data.body:
I'd like to pick up the discussion off the back of the related issue #2516 here.

Given that both the suggestion here and the one raised in my issue would require extension owners to change their setup.py, I believe this gives us an opportunity to revisit the approach to how Cython extensions should be built and distributed.

As such, I would like to promote the approach highlighted in the other ticket where Cython extensions are shipped with their generated files and that those distributions are built like any other C/C++ extensions. This would allow for the setup.py to remain clear of any Cython specific parameters. The build system would only need to be more capable when the user wishes to explicitly run `cythonize` on their code.

This additional functionality would ideally be built into setuptools, for example using the setuptools_scm approach. This allows Cython to be detected and only allow `cythonize` to be invoked (perhaps through --cythonize flag to build_ext) if the Cython module exists (I believe the old cython integration into setuptools did something like this). There can also be a new argument for `setup()` which could represent `cythonize_args: {**kwargs}`. 

The more difficult part about this approach is the fact that for a Cython extension to be built by distutils/setuptools without invoking cythonize, all sources must be specified as their generated filename and not their pyx one which is a shift in mindset and also potentially a non-trivial implementation which applies the reverse transition of .cpp/.c -> .pyx through source file discovery, alternatively this could be done in cythonize itself.

In principle, yes, such a setup would be great. In practice, `cythonize()` infers several things from the sources, such as further source files and dependencies (and as a result the decision if a rebuild is required), distutils configuration, C vs. C++, …

Cython now stores all this in a JSON blob at the beginning of each generated source file, so teaching setuptools how to interpret that could solve all problems. And triggering this behaviour is easy due to the unique comment at the beginning of Cython generated files. – Assuming that users want this and do not provide their own setup. Because that could lead to conflicts. There's nothing worse than smart tools that force users to fight them.

I would like to see this logic pushed up to setuptools (by default at least). We had some discussions about this at the workshop in Cernay, but I can't seem to find a pointer to the notes. @embray did you have those handy?

@robertwb Hey, sorry I dropped the ball on that since then.  I still have my notes from our discussion and will dig them up--it's something I'm still interested in helping with.

See also #1514 which brings up my original proposal--which was to add a `build_cython` distutils command, to add an explicit build stage / `setup.py` command that wraps `cythonize()`.  I think this is still a good idea.  But as we discussed in Cernay, and as @scoder raises, there is a little more to it than just adding the command, such as adding metadata to `.pyx` files, etc.

I still don't understand why everybody wants to **NOT** depend on Cython at build-time. First of all, what's wrong with Cython as dependency? Second, if you're going to add a minimal build system as new package, then you'll need a dependency anyway.

> Cython now stores all this in a JSON blob at the beginning of each generated source file, so teaching setuptools how to interpret that could solve all problems.

I doubt that. The logic in `cythonize()` to deal with dependencies, `# distutils` declarations, path names for include files is a lot more complicated than you think. It will certainly work for simple projects, but I'm pretty sure that it will break down for sufficiently complicated use cases.

@scoder
The solution I'm suggesting should not rely on such meta data.
As I understand, you only need this meta data during the file generation process, which is only ever needed during the cythonize step. 

What I'm suggesting allows us to skip the cythonize step entirely by explicitly specifying the generated file. Only if the user runs it in some sort of "--cythonize" mode, should we attempt to invoke cythonize. However for this all that is needed imo is to discover the presence of Cython artefacts (by scanning the source repository as highlighted above) and substituting them instead of the generated files. After this we still invoke cythonize which would do all the more complex generation steps that would use this meta-data at that point, and cythonize would affectively reverse the substitution following its generation logic.

Perhaps I'm missing something but I'm not sure what distutils needs from the Cython meta-data during the build process presuming it is NOT running the "cythonize" path, but just compiling C/C++ sources?

@jdemeyer
Speaking from my perspective only, the benefits of not depending on Cython are:
- You separate the cython step from the build step, if you have non trivial cythonize scenario (e.g. shared .pxd assets which are not distributed with your source repo). In my organisation it would make sense to distribute .pxd with our C++ libraries over an internal DPKG distribution and when it comes to shipping to PyPI we would rather not expose this complex process.
- If we manage to add this support into say setuptools then no extra build dependencies would be required

> I'm not sure what distutils needs from the Cython meta-data during the build process

Lots of it: dependencies, include paths, compiler flags,...

> You separate the cython step from the build step, if you have non trivial cythonize scenario (e.g. shared .pxd assets which are not distributed with your source repo).

And why do you consider it a benefit to do it this way?

I would argue the opposite: by running Cython in `setup.py`, you are sure that the cythonized file are up to date and you can simplify the build/packaging logic.

Other difficulties can include making sure that your Cython code is compiled with the *correct* version of Cython.  E.g. maybe there are some versions that have bugs that affect your code.  And sometimes users who just want to `pip install` your package have a new problem when they also have to get the right Cython built and installed.  

For you it's no big deal because you're knee-deep in Cython, but I have plenty of experience distributing packages that happen to use Cython to users, and it's much easier for both them and me to ship them pre-cythonized sources.

Then we have the problem of what compiler they have installed, etc. but there's obviously less we can do about that.

> Other difficulties can include making sure that your Cython code is compiled with the correct version of Cython. E.g. maybe there are some versions that have bugs that affect your code. And sometimes users who just want to pip install your package have a new problem when they also have to get the right Cython built and installed.

I see your point but those are solved problems. You can specify a versioned Cython dependency in `setup_requires` in the `setup()` call. And a proper continuous integration setup should be able to test multiple Cython versions.

To be clear: I'm not in principle against making packages buildable without Cython. I'm just trying to compare cost versus benefit. To me, the benefit (not having a dependency on Cython) seems smaller than the cost (increased complexity in the build/packaging system). So I would rather focus the development effort on better integration of Cython within setuptools (#1514) instead of making Cython optional.

> The logic in cythonize() to deal with dependencies, # distutils declarations, path names for include files is a lot more complicated than you think.

The idea would be to move most of that logic into an external package that Cython _and_ Cython implemented packages could depend on.

> You can specify a versioned Cython dependency in setup_requires in the setup() call.

Which then means that you might have to download something at build time (which is usually different from deployment time). Jeroen, I don't understand why you _want_ to require users to deal with Cython as an end-user dependency, when we can certainly do without. It is an important design goal of Cython to make the emitted C code "generate once!" and simple to use in as many environments as possible. Building C-implemented extensions is something that Python has built-in. Everything beyond that should be imposed on Cython users but not on their end-users.

> The idea would be to move most of that logic into an external package that Cython and Cython implemented packages could depend on.

So basically move the existing `Cython/Build/Dependencies.py` to an external package?

> I don't understand why you want to require users to deal with Cython as an end-user dependency

I think I answered that above: it's not that I'm fundamentally against that. It's more that I compare the advantages and disadvantages and I see more disadvantages than advantages.

> So basically move the existing Cython/Build/Dependencies.py to an external package?

(answering to myself here) That actually sounds like a much better idea than parsing JSON metadata in the `.c` files. It would be easier to implement (the code already exists) and we know that it works.

> It is an important design goal of Cython to make the emitted C code "generate once!"

There are at least two cases where this is non-trivial to achieve:

1. Code which uses the compile-time environment (`IF` statements). Typically, this is done because code needs to be different depending on platform, Python version or optional dependencies.

2. Cross-package `cimport`. This means that the generated C code of package A also depends on another package B. If package B is not careful to preserve its C API, then stuff can break if package A is cythonized with a different version of package B.
I consider both cases acceptable limitations.

I thought about the proposal by @eyakimov-bbg some more, and I really like it. He has provided a simple example implementation here, which isn't complete (lacks JSON support), but gives the idea:
https://github.com/eyakimov-bbg/python-testmodule/blob/cython_build_ext/setup.py

Here's a spelled out proposal:

1) We implement this in setuptools.

2) Users should create `Extension` instances again, but list the generated `.c` / `.cpp` files in their list of sources. This is backwards compatible with the current Cython support in setuptools, which is only triggered by `.pyx` files.

3) By default, setuptools will run over the list of extensions, and check every source file with a `.c*` file extension for the start bytes `b"/* Generated by Cython "`.
3a) If the marker is found, it will read the JSON meta-data in the section between `/* BEGIN: Cython Metadata` and `END: Cython Metadata */` and add all `distutils` related options to the `Extension`. This is a straight forward thing to do, because the information is right there, named as distutils wants it, including all file dependencies that Cython found.
3b) It is an error if an extension source file does not exist. setuptools could help here by giving a nice error message if it finds a file with the same name but `.pyx` as extension.

4) We add a new `--rebuild-with-cython` option (or `--cythonize`, as Evgeny suggested) to setuptools that, when passed to `setup.py`, does the following.
4a) (maybe) If Cython is not installed, the latest version will be pip-installed. Optionally, `--rebuild-with-cython` could accept a version as argument, i.e. `--rebuild-with-cython=0.28.5`. This could be passed from a Makefile etc., so that end-users of a source checkout don't have to care about it.
4b) With this option, `setuptools` will change its behaviour, and for every `.c*` source file of an extension (that has the `Generated by Cython` marker?) check for a corresponding `.pyx` file immediately. If it exists, it will collect this `Extension` in a list of Cython extension modules, replace the source file name with the `.pyx` file, and in the end, call `cythonize()` on the list of Cython extension modules that it found.

I like this proposal, because it keeps all Cython specific functionality in Cython's `cythonize()`, while allowing Cython sdists to build in a straight forward way in `setuptools` without Cython as a dependency. Only source checkouts require a special option, which I find acceptable.

I don't like this:
```
class cythonize_build_ext(build_ext):
```

Experience from SageMath shows that it is better to add cythonization as separate build step, not as part of `build_ext`. See #1514 for reasons why.
I care more about the general approach than specific implementation details at this point, also because the details will end up in setuptools and not Cython.

One key feature that I'd like to preserve is that Cython is required, and
the .c files rebuilt, iff the .pyx file (or any of its transitive pxd
dependencies) are changed (i.e. newer than the corresponding .c files).

To me it feels odd (and error prone) listing the generated .c files as the
source files. Especially if we can modify upstream (setuptools) to
understand what the "real" sources are. I would like whatever logic we ship
upstream to be relatively lightweight and easy to maintain, which was the
goal of the JSON header (everything is pre-computed, and if stuff changed,
we must require and invoke Cython).

I also thought about a simple `setuptools.cythonize(modules, **kwargs)` function that would do the `.pyx` -> `Extension` dance based on the JSON metadata if the `.c*` file exists, and otherwise require/import Cython and pass all arguments on to its real `cythonize()` function. Users would then always import `cythonize` from `setuptools` instead of `Cython.Build`, and it would run Cython as needed.

Regarding the "rebuild on modifications" bit, that's a bit risky, because I would never want an sdist to execute Cython on build, which could happen if the original file modification times got lost on unpacking for some reason. I would prefer if it was an explicit request to rebuild the sources. However, I do understand that it's worth making the life easy also for developers of Cython code …

Yeah, this beats everyone writing their own... If we're going to integrate
with setuptools, it probably be nicer to avoid the explicit call-cythonize
pattern.

> Regarding the "rebuild on modifications" bit, that's a bit risky, because
> I would never want an sdist to execute Cython on build, which could happen
> if the original file modification times got lost on unpacking for some
> reason. I would prefer if it was an explicit request to rebuild the
> sources. However, I do understand that it's worth making the life easy also
> for developers of Cython code…
>
Modification times are pretty well preserved these days, but if they're
lost it's more likely they'd all be set to the same thing, and requiring
strictly older C files should handle this gracefully. We can make it opt
out, but it's annoying and counterintuitive to require extra commands iff
cython source was modified (and can lead to inconsistent state that could
be hard to debug).

Also of note I'd like to keep the globbing behavior.

Especially since it's really difficult to call it only if necessary and at the right time, e.g. setup.py is run for other reasons than a build, or if Cython isn't installed before setup.py runs.

Would this new build system replace cythonize, or be an alternative in the case where the cython code can be pre-compiled? My reason for asking is that h5py depends on being able to use IF statements to be able to match the build configuration of HDF5 (so cython is always a build dependency of h5py).
Yes, it would replace cythonize, but in the h5py case one would not ship generated .c files so Cython would remain a hard dependency and be invoked at compile time.

I'm not clear what you mean by "replace cythonize".  My vision was to keep the existing "cythonize" interface, maybe refactor it a bit, and make it easier to integrate into a setup.py command (plus the other bits we discussed about moving more metadata into the pyx and c files and reading from them as able.
Also see #477.

I mean, I have personal experience from shipping Cython-generated C code in Astropy's source tarball that it's quite useful and I've never heard of problems resulting from this. If anything it lends to stability.

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Implement minimal build system
